head.title: Warriors' Davis Shoves Mavericks to Brink of Elimination

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/Sports/Pro Basketball/National Basketball Association/Golden State Warriors

hedline.hl1: Warriors' Davis Shoves Mavericks to Brink of Elimination

block.p: They are underdogs no more. In fact, the Golden State Warriors may need to get used to a new identity.
The Warriors defeated the Dallas Mavericks again Sunday night, 103-99, and are now one victory away from completing one of the biggest upsets in N.B.A. history.
They are underdogs no more. In fact, the Golden State Warriors may need to get used to a new identity.
The Warriors defeated the Dallas Mavericks again Sunday night, 103-99, and are now one victory away from completing one of the biggest upsets in N.B.A. history.

Baron Davis scored 33 points, including the layup that put the Warriors ahead to stay. Golden State, the eighth-seeded team in the Western Conference, has a 3-1 lead in the best-of-seven series and can oust the top-seeded Mavericks on Tuesday in Dallas.
Only eight teams in league history have won a series after trailing by 3-1, and Dirk Nowitzki was surprisingly candid when assessing his team's chances a day earlier.
''If we lose,'' Nowitzki told reporters Saturday, ''this season is pretty much over.''
Neither his coach, Avery Johnson, nor his former coach, the Warriors' Don Nelson, endorsed the notion.
''I think they're capable of winning three in a row at any time,'' Nelson said before tip-off. ''They won 17 at one time, as I recall.''
Still, things felt desperate enough in the Dallas locker room that Jason Terry and Jerry Stackhouse called a players-only meeting Saturday, ''and they aired some things out,'' Johnson said.

Dallas led by as many as 9 points in the first half, but the Warriors never faded. They finished with a flourish, as Davis banked in a 3-pointer from 49 feet at the halftime buzzer, tying the score at 49-49.

The momentum, and the deafening roar, carried into the third quarter, as Jason Richardson and Stephen Jackson opened the period with consecutive 3-pointers. Dallas briefly took control, using a 21-7 run to take a 70-62 lead, their biggest margin in two games here. But the Warriors stormed back. Davis led the charge, scoring their last 8 points of the quarter to tie the game at 77-77 by the end of the quarter.

In the final 1 minute 16 seconds of the period, Davis had a free throw, a layup scored off his own missed foul shot, a 3-pointer, a block and finally, a stolen inbounds pass that he converted for a fast-break dunk.

A record crowd of 20,672 again serenaded Davis with chants of ''M.V.P.,'' while Nowitzki -- a leading contender to win that award -- again came up small. Nowitzki, who has yet to have a big game in the series, finished with 23 points, including a pair of desperation 3-pointers in the final minute.
